recordings.loc: Derby Creek, Council Road, Nome Census Area, Alaska
recordings.rmk: natural vocalization; song in display flight and calls from the ground from a male bird along a road through tundra with isolated willows.  During the song flight the bird would give the first series of calls while in flight, and then the terminal, double-parted notes upon landing.  In the accelerating nasal call series the bird would stretch its neck out while calling.

recordings.loc: Derby Creek, Council Road, Nome Census Area, Alaska

Clearly Lagopus lagopus cocks are heard throughout, like at 02:43.1 and 02:22.4. My question here is what the other calls are. There are two distinctly different call types, type 1 heard at 00:14.8, 00:43, 01:00.4  and 00:08.5, type 2 at 00:02, 00:45 and 01:27.4. Are they both Lagopus lagopus hens?

recordings.loc: Hope Woodlands Moor, intersection of Pennine Way and Snake Road, Peak District National Park, England
recordings.rmk: One bird (part of a larger group of around 20 birds) in in very low roadside shrubs. Weather was incredibly misty. Recording filtered slightly to remove noise of passing cars (as the bird was just along the busy Snake road, this was the only useable part of a larger recording). Recorded with internal microphone of Edirol R09-HR.

recordings.loc: Hogan Creek - Station 3, Denali National Park, AK
recordings.file-name: XC177475-DENAHOG3_20120601_053515 Willow Ptarmigan call, American Tree Sparrow background.mp3
recordings.rmk: An area of dwarf birch, ericaceous shrubs, and lichen above Hogan Creek - a small, fast moving stream bordered by ~2 m willow shrubs and spruce.  This site was approximately 450 m from the creek at the very closest.

recordings.loc: Hogan Creek - Station 3, Denali National Park, AK
recordings.rmk: An area of dwarf birch, ericaceous shrubs, and lichen above Hogan Creek - a small, fast moving stream bordered by ~2 m willow shrubs and spruce.  This site was approximately 450 m from the creek at the very closest.

In an open thicket of relatively tall (1.5 m) felt-leaf Salix and compact (0.3 m tall) Potentilla shrub.  Ground cover was mainly sedges and grasses.  Site was at the base of Polychrome Mountain and about 100 meters east of a tributary stream of the Toklat River (about 500-700 meters distant.)
Flight song.  Low-shrub / sedge habitat in the Kantishna Hills with a deep, spongy moss underlayer.  Stunted spruce about 200 feet up a shallow slope.
Cutted out long silence
Snowing and wind! Telinga stereo H4n tripod
